quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 4 Quiz 8
quiz.subtitle: 4.8: Grignard Reagents
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Synthesis and reactions of organomagnesium compounds

questions.question: Which of the following describes the general formula of a Grignard reagent?
questions.explanation: A Grignard reagent consists of an alkyl or aryl group ($R$) bonded to a magnesium atom, which is in turn bonded to a halogen ($X$).

questions.question: What is the typical solvent used for the preparation and storage of Grignard reagents?
options: Dry ether (e.g., diethyl ether or THF)
questions.explanation: Ethers stabilize the magnesium atom through coordination and must be 'dry' because Grignard reagents react explosively with water.

questions.question: In a Grignard reagent, what is the electronic nature of the carbon atom attached to the magnesium?
questions.explanation: Because magnesium is much less electronegative than carbon, the $C-Mg$ bond is highly polarized, giving the carbon a strong partial negative charge.

questions.question: What happens when a Grignard reagent reacts with water or an alcohol?
options: It is protonated to form an alkane
It forms a more stable Grignard reagent
It acts as a catalyst for polymerization
questions.explanation: Grignard reagents are very strong bases ($pK_{a} \approx 50$) and will instantly strip a proton from any source containing an $-OH$ or $-NH$ group.

questions.question: A Grignard reagent reacts with formaldehyde ($HCHO$) followed by acid workup to produce:
questions.explanation: Formaldehyde has only hydrogens attached to the carbonyl carbon, so adding one $R$ group results in a primary alcohol.

questions.question: To synthesize a tertiary (3°) alcohol using a Grignard reagent, which carbonyl compound should be used?
questions.explanation: Ketones already have two alkyl groups; adding a third from the Grignard reagent creates a tertiary alcohol.

questions.question: What organic product is formed when a Grignard reagent reacts with dry ice ($CO_{2}$) followed by hydrolysis?
questions.explanation: The nucleophilic $R$ group attacks the $CO_{2}$ carbon, and subsequent acidification yields $R-COOH$.

questions.question: Which of the following is a limitation of Grignard reagents?
options: They cannot be formed in the presence of acidic functional groups like $-OH$ or $-COOH$
They only react with noble gases
They are only stable at temperatures above $200^{\circ}C$
They can only be made from fluorine-containing compounds
questions.explanation: Because they are such strong bases, they will destroy themselves by reacting with any acidic protons present in the same molecule.

questions.question: Which of the following reactions would correctly produce methylmagnesium bromide?
questions.explanation: Grignard reagents are prepared by reacting an alkyl halide with magnesium turnings in an anhydrous ether solvent.

questions.question: When an aldehyde (other than formaldehyde) reacts with a Grignard reagent, the resulting product is:
questions.explanation: Aldehydes have one $R$ group and one $H$; adding a second $R$ group from the Grignard reagent results in a secondary alcohol.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a strong grasp of organometallic reactivity.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. You understand the synthetic power of Grignard reagents.
scoreMessages.50: Keep it up! Remember that Grignard reagents are both strong nucleophiles and strong bases.
scoreMessages.0: Review the reaction of Grignard reagents with different carbonyl compounds.
